questiontext.text: Below are listed some possible behaviours of a differentiable function \(f\).  Select all those behaviours that are indeed possible.

generalfeedback.text:
The function \(f(x) = e^x\) has no stationary points and no roots.

The function \(f(x) = x\) has no stationary points and exactly one root.

The function \(f(x) = x^2 + 1\) has exactly one stationary point and no roots.

The function \(f(x) = x^2\) has exactly one stationary point and exactly one root.

The function \(f(x) = x^2 -1\) has exactly one stationary point and two roots.

Between any two zeros of a differentiable function there must be a stationary point.  We have not proved it but a sketch should make it clear.  So two zeros but no stationary points, and three zeros and only one stationary point are both impossible behaviours.

answer.text: \(f\) has no stationary points and no roots.
\(f\) has no stationary points and exactly one root.
\(f\) has no stationary points and exactly two roots.
\(f\) has exactly one stationary point and no roots.
\(f\) has exactly one stationary point and exactly one root.
\(f\) has exactly one stationary point and exactly two roots.
\(f\) has exactly one stationary point and exactly three roots.
